Joseph's Blog a series of my experiences and thoughts

HackingEDU Hackathon

26 Oct 2015

Fresh off my hackathon victory at Dubhacks 2015, I flew to HackingEDU in San Mateo, California, an event which was set to host 1500+ hackers from across the world.

Once again, I was drawn to the event due to its substantial nature (both in terms of competitors, prizes, and travel reimbursements). Upon arriving at the venue (San Mateo Event Center - which was a random area south of San Fransisco), my speculations were correct. In addition to the numerous sponsors, I was able to get mentorship and listen to talks from some of the greatest minds in tech:

  • Sal Khan - Founder of Khan Academy
  • Sam Altman - President at Y-Combinator
  • Andrew Sutherland - Founder at Quizlet
  • Jack Herrick - Founder at WikiHow
  • Tony Conrad - Founder of About.me
  • Mike Osie - CIO at Chegg
  • Laurie Voss - Founder at NPM
  • Guillermo Rauch - Founder at Socket.io
  • Randy Turbush - Founder at Apache

    • â€¦ and many many more.

    As for the hackathon itself, I teamed up with Bryan from Berkley, who I met at the event, and a Clement from Waterloo. Although Bryan had never coded before, we were able to work effectively within a team to create a product that satisfied a growing pain-point in the education industry. To learn more about our product, please visit this link.

    In the end, we were able to pitch our product to some prominent industry professionals and make a positive impression. So much so that we WON the largest cash prize at the event - the Clusterpoint Award. This award capped off an amazing experience - one full of great people, great food, and great experiences. In addition to the event, I had an opportunity to tour Palo Alto and the Stanford Campus. I would recommend the event to anyone planning on applying to HackingEDU 2016!
